hashtag
#PsychologicalSafety doesn't mean people are always comfortable and conversations are always easy. It's about the ability to have those tough conversations that lead to growth without fear of repercussions.

Fantastic piece byabout the perils of equating "nice" with having high emotional intelligence (and high psychological safety), featuring research from myself,, and.

Read in:

hashtag
#PsychologicalSafety is a win-win-win.

When employees feel safe and supported bringing their full selves to the table‚Äîall their thoughts, ideas, questions, and (yes) flaws‚Äîit lifts up the people, the work, and the company...

Excited to have Vanessa Druskat's fantastic new book in my hands. A great resource for anyone interested in building resilient 
hashtag
#teams.

This provocative and smart article by Gautam Mukunda is worth a read. 

hashtag
#AI as a "Yes Man", a great 
hashtag
#tennis example that rings true for me, plus, I've had similar experiences and admit to enjoying the (dangerous) feeling of being right...

On August 13th, I‚Äôll be joining Costco's former CFO Richard Galanti for a practical, fast-paced working session hosted by Chief Executive Group. We'll explore how leaders can eliminate friction and create the clarity and trust needed for action.

I'd love to see some of you there! Register at the link:

So thrilled to have this wonderful book in my hands, hot off the press. Labwork to Leadership by Jen Heemstra is an absolutely invaluable guide for scientific leaders everywhere.

If you've read
, you might recognize Jen from the beginning of Chapter 2: Eureka! Her interview on learning and discovery in the lab was a perfect intro for explaining
.

"I want to create a campus culture where failure is reframed as an essential component of learning, innovation and personal growth."

This brings me such joy! I love seeing colleges working to help students develop the intellectual and emotional skills they need to navigate uncertainty and
.

Kudos to, Dean of Engaged Education at, and the ALEX department for this wonderful initiative.

Read more here:

I'm proud to share the new article with my amazing coauthors Nicki Macklin and Tom Lee. 

It's Nicki whose important research on
inspired us to
and share insights about how kindness drives
and
‚Äî and why it matters.

Psychologists and neuroscientists have discovered that, far too often for our own health and success, a kind of automatic sense that we're right blinds us‚Äîthe confirmation bias. We literally fail to see evidence that goes against what we believe.

But being wrong is part of being alive in a complex and uncertain world.

The best antidote to this type of thinking is to be curious, and to be humble. Prioritize learning over knowing. Seek out other perspectives. Ask yourself: how do I know that I'm right?

üìï, my book on

Don't know where to start when building a psychologically safe workplace?

Here's the advice I gaveon how HR leaders can implement practices that will benefit teams and organizations at every level.

Of course, this is just a starting point. I'd love to hear what strategies have worked for you!

What an honor from The Business Excellence Institute! To be recognized for my work is always a pinch-me moment.

I'd love to see some familiar faces at the induction this September in Dublin‚Ä¶if you'll be in the area, grab a ticket:

Now this is excellence! Reframing (let's face it, critical) feedback as a kind of compliment‚Äîthe person felt able (yes, safe) to convey her concerns. 

Beautiful story fromby

An eagerness to learn is essential for innovation. 

But the way we learn‚Äîand the order in which we partake in various learning activities‚Äîcan make the difference between effective growth and potential missed opportunities.

,,, and I studied more than 160 innovation teams and found that the key to faster, clearer progress is:

Structured learning üë∑üèóÔ∏è

Our research, published in theJournal, highlights four distinct types of learning behaviors used by high-performing teams and examines variations in the sequence and blend of these types of team learning.

Without a deliberate rhythm, teams risk becoming overwhelmed by continual information intake, leading to confusion and burnout. But by honing a team's ideal 'learning rhythm,' you can avoid overwhelm and instead focus on strategic decision-making and sustainable innovation.

Read our research summary now in the:

Elite failure practitioners around the world and throughout history‚Äîathletes, inventors, entrepreneurs, scientists‚Äîhave taught me a great deal about what it takes to be tolerant to failures of all kinds. 

What motivates EFPs to endure and befriend failure?

An unrelenting drive to solve new problems that advance their craft‚Äînot through philosophic contemplation, but by interacting with the world around them. Testing things out. Experimenting. They‚Äôre willing to act!

The good news? We all have the ability to foster this unique mix of skills necessary for
within ourselves.

üìï
:

ùó™ùóµùòÜ ùó±ùóº ùòÄùóºùó∫ùó≤ ùó∂ùóªùóªùóºùòÉùóÆùòÅùó∂ùóºùóª ùòÅùó≤ùóÆùó∫ùòÄ ùó±ùó≤ùóπùó∂ùòÉùó≤ùóø ùòÑùóµùó∂ùóπùó≤ ùóºùòÅùóµùó≤ùóøùòÄ ùòÄùòÅùóÆùóπùóπ‚Äîùó±ùó≤ùòÄùóΩùó∂ùòÅùó≤ ùòÑùóºùóøùó∏ùó∂ùóªùó¥ ùó∑ùòÇùòÄùòÅ ùóÆùòÄ ùóµùóÆùóøùó±?

In research conducted with,, and, we studied more than 160 innovation teams‚Äîincluding those in a Fortune Global 500 company‚Äîand found that it's not just how much teams learn that matters, but when and how they learn.

We identified four core modes of team learning:
ùó•ùó≤ùó≥ùóπùó≤ùòÖùó∂ùòÉùó≤ ‚Äî assessing goals, roles, and strategies
ùóòùòÖùóΩùó≤ùóøùó∂ùó∫ùó≤ùóªùòÅùóÆùóπ ‚Äî brainstorming, prototyping, testing new ideas
ùóñùóºùóªùòÅùó≤ùòÖùòÅùòÇùóÆùóπ ‚Äî scanning the environment for trends, signals, and shifts
ùó©ùó∂ùó∞ùóÆùóøùó∂ùóºùòÇùòÄ ‚Äî drawing lessons from others who‚Äôve done similar work

The most effective teams didn‚Äôt try to do everything at once. They began and ended with reflexive learning, anchoring their work in shared understanding. They placed exploratory learning (experimental and contextual) in the middle. This rhythm‚Äîreflection ‚Üí exploration ‚Üí reflection‚Äîhelped them reduce friction, integrate insights, and build real momentum.

We also found that vicarious learning can be combined with reflexive learning in the same project phase with positive results. But when teams mixed reflexive with experimental or contextual learning in the same phase, performance suffered.

ùóßùóµùó≤ ùòÅùóÆùó∏ùó≤ùóÆùòÑùóÆùòÜ: Innovation doesn‚Äôt thrive on more learning. It thrives on structured learning. Teams that sequence and separate their learning activities make faster, clearer progress.

We‚Äôve summarized the findings from our research, published in‚Äîa leading journal in organizational research‚Äîin this newarticle. Link in comments.
Great piece by IMD with a spot on call out about Satya Nadella's feedback-seeking to build a culture of learn-it-alls.

The best leaders show up as learners, not as know-it-alls. 

I spoke with Rodger Dean Duncan on the LeaderSHOP podcast all about how to build a culture where people speak up, learn from
, and work through uncertainty.

Listen here:

Angela Duckworth has identified a paradox in AI and education... I think it can best be described as a trap. The ever-present trap of choosing easy options today only to discover that you'll pay for it later. Our challenge is how to help ourselves and others avoid such traps by rediscovering the motivation and the desire to do hard things today.

Too often, we go into important conversations ready to argue our point without stopping to ask what we might be missing. 

shares a practical tool to help leaders pause, reflect, and enter tough moments with more
and less certainty...a great read for anyone looking to improve their curiosity muscle!

Read in:

A small nugget from my conversation with the folks at Workhuman. 

Building a truly fearless org requires work at all levels. Education, leadership messaging, and feedback are great ways to start!

When we talk about 
hashtag
#burnout, the focus is often on workload, boundaries, or other tangible obstacles that inform our common perception of what 'overworked' can look like. 

But the emotional and cognitive exhaustion that comes with interpersonal anxiety also plays a large role.

When teams lack
‚Äîthat is, when they feel unsafe speaking up, asking for help, raising questions, or flagging problems‚Äîemployees are much more likely to experience workplace stress, and eventually, burnout.

I explore this topic and more with the wonderfulfor his Culture Matters podcast‚Ä¶take a listen at the link:

Second place can feel disastrous, but the sting of ‚Äúalmost‚Äù is less a verdict on your potential than an invitation to hone it. 

Coming up just short can serve as a springboard for growth, offering the chance to learn, adapt, and come back stronger‚Äîprovided you choose to seize the opportunity.

My new article, written with the inimitable, is all about how our near misses can teach us more than our successes.

Read now inü•àüìñ

Another great article by Jim Detert - his unique blend of insight, rigor, and practical suggestions shines through this new guide to speaking up and standing up. With specific phrases to experiment with (and practice), the ideas he shares can, and should be put to immediate use.
Magnificent post.
Thanks Jay Lau for this terrific summary from the Harvard Chan School of Public Health Michaela Kerrissey

Unfortunately, we are hardwired to feel as if we know‚Äîas if we see reality itself rather than a version of reality filtered through our biases, backgrounds, or expertise.

Once we‚Äôre humble enough to admit we don‚Äôt know, we‚Äôre ready to approach situations in a new way.

This is how we can make more effective decisions, pivot when things aren't working, and learn from
on the path to success.

It's also how we can see other perspectives, break down our biases, and grow as both individuals and a society.

Quote from page 193 in
:
Roberto Ferraro knows how to convey my more than 1000 words in a (compelling) image instead...

Failure is an inevitable step toward successful innovation. So, instead of shaming and blaming, organizations need to stay curious and learn from failure if they want meaningful growth. 

I spoke with the team atfor their Ready to Transform podcast about why we need to normalize the discomfort that can come with learning, especially in today's ever-changing world.

Take a listen wherever you get podcasts, or watch the full episode here:
Is Accountability contagious? Read on for a thoughtful take by Claire Gray...

Creating systems to catch and correct 
hashtag
#failure before it happens is one of the best tools we have to fight against basic and complex failures...aka the 'wrong kinds of wrong'!

These failure prevention systems aren't revolutionary. But few companies or families take the time to get them in place. My favorite, blameless reporting, is especially effective for enabling early detection of potential harm.

Do you practice any of these systems? If not, which one do you think you'd be most likely to implement?

In our uncertain world, learning how to lead effectively is more critical than ever.

Next Monday, June 16 at 1PM EST, I'll be joiningandto discuss the current challenges leaders are facing, plus strategies for creating effective change amidst uncertainty and disruption.

I hope to see you there! Register for the webinar:

Though it may seem counterintuitive, failure can be a gift. It can bring clarity about which of our abilities need work, and insight about our true passions. 

Failing a multivariable calculus exam in college was caused by my inadequate studying. But it forced me to ask myself hard questions about the work that I truly loved‚Äîand that which I was likely doing to please or impress others.

That was a gift, even if it didn't feel like one at the time. In what ways has
shown up as a gift in your life?

Quote from page 264 in my book on
,
üìï

We're about to hit the three month mark since The Fearless Organization launched with LIT Videobooks, and it‚Äôs been so rewarding to see how the conversation around 
hashtag
#PsychologicalSafety continues to grow.

The Fearless Org videobook covers the core principles of psychological safety, how to create a culture where people feel empowered to speak up, and why the best teams aren‚Äôt just productive‚Äîthey‚Äôre fearless. It's a wonderful addition to any summer learning lineup!

And for any HR and L&D leaders who follow me, you can explore the entire LIT library with two weeks of complimentary access to LIT for Teams. I've been told to mention "Fearless" when you fill out the formüòâüëâ

When dealing with complex failures‚Äîfailures caused by the accumulation of many "little things"‚ÄîI like to reference Dr. James Reason's Swiss cheese model üßÄ

Holes in the Swiss cheese are likened to small process errors. A hole in your block of cheese can be seen as a flaw, but these holes are discrete and contained, leaving the cheese intact.

But sometimes the Swiss cheese holes line up, despite being separated by time or distance, to create a tunnel through which complex failure flows unimpeded.

This visual model helps emphasize the importance of adding layers of defense to combat system failures.

Learning from past failures, welcoming false alarms, and building a culture of
all increase the likelihood that teams will catch and correct these small errors before something catastrophic occurs.

We can't erase human error, but we can aim for zero harm.

in my book

hashtag

Are you operating in a healthy 
hashtag
#failure culture? Here's a simple checklist, pulled from my book 
hashtag
#RightKindOfWrong, to help you make an assessment. 

As counterintuitive as it might seem, all positive news is not a positive sign.

Organizations and teams that have
will hear more negatives‚Äînot because their teams are less capable‚Äîbut because they feel comfortable speaking up about inevitable problems, concerns, and questions.

So, did your team score more 'greens' or 'reds'? Let me know!

I'm inspired by this thoughtful article by Rositsa Genovska applying 
hashtag
#IntelligentFailure principles to 
hashtag
#AI strategy. Super insightful list of practices.

So, what does 
hashtag
#PsychologicalSafety really mean? I sat down with Harvard Business Review to unpack the all-too-frequently misunderstood concept. 

For more, you can read my article with the wonderful:

One of my favorite quotes about learning from failure comes from fourteen-year-old New Yorker Tanitoluwa Adewumi, who became a United States‚Äô national chess master at age 10. 

When accepting the title, his words were well beyond his age: ‚ÄúI say to myself that I never lose, that I only learn. Because when you lose, you have to make a mistake to lose that game. So, you learn from that mistake, and so you learn [overall]. So losing is the way of winning for yourself.‚Äù

So true, Tani! Learning from our missteps is the key to overall success.

üìï Quote taken from
:

Accountability is not a 'dirty word'‚Äîit is a privilege and a power. 

I see accountability as psychological ownership; your ability to own your contribution to results. We need accountability to innovate, create, and achieve.

Listen to my full talk with the superbon her
podcast‚Ä¶link below!

Fantastic article from Marcel Schwantes‚Äîfeaturing insights from my work with Michaela Kerrissey!

is so often misrepresented‚Ä¶ it's not about being nice or everyone getting their way, and it certainly does not come at the expense of performance. Quite the opposite! PS is necessary for healthy, innovative, and productive work environments.

Read now:

After writing an essay for Scientific American‚Äôs parenting column, I had a little fun rewriting the table on page 64 of 
hashtag
#RightKindOfWrong (how to tell if a failure is intelligent) into a guide for parents. 

My goal is to help parents ENCOURAGE their kids to take smart risks‚Ä¶ not to be overly prescriptive, but rather to illustrate that it can be fun to try new things, even when they don‚Äôt always work out as hoped.

I'll leave the essay link in the comments for anyone curious as to why it's crucial to let our kids fail well!

I‚Äôm excited to share a new course I‚Äôm teaching through Harvard Business School Online: Dynamic Teaming. 

It‚Äôs a new addition to the HBS Online portfolio, designed to give professionals everywhere access to essential business concepts through an interactive learning experience.

The Dynamic Teaming course explores the tools, processes, and skills required to build agile, adaptable teams and lead them in rapidly changing work environments. It‚Äôs just one of multiple transformative learning experiences offered by HBS Online, which includes a comprehensive portfolio of vital business topics, ranging from leadership, strategy, and finance to entrepreneurship, digital transformation, and the intersection between business and society.

This is going to be a good one! You can explore the full range of courses and discover how HBS Online can help advance your career here:

I call "failing well" a science for a reason‚Ä¶ because it's much more than a catchy term. 

Failing well describes the systematic approach to understanding our failures: how we think about, talk about, and learn from them. The result? A healthier relationship to failure and an improved ability to pursue intelligent risks.

It takes practice and dedication, but everyone can improve their ability to fail well. These five practices are a great way to start!

Learning > Knowing 

The act of learning is a conscious one. Be curious, ask questions, and challenge your existing beliefs. It's the only way to grow beyond the status quo and progress‚Äîas individuals, communities, and society as a whole.

Thank you to theteam for having me on their podcast to discuss one of my favorite topics: learning!

in May. If you're planning to attend, come say hello:

hashtag
#ATD25 conference in Washington DC from May 19-21‚Ä¶will you be there too? 

If you're planning to attend, come say hello!

A quick reminder that my fireside chat with Ronak S. of LIT Videobooks is tomorrow, April 14th...

Join us at 4:00 PM ET to explore how leaders can create psychologically safe environments for their teams and foster a culture where everyone is comfortable speaking up.

Register here:
Congrats Jayshree Seth. Science Advocates have never been more needed; your clear voice is making a difference!

Positively blunt‚Ä¶ I love it Jake Breeden!

Just as 
hashtag
#PsychologicalSafety doesn't mean "being nice" or feeling comfortable at all times, being blunt isn't inherently bad.

Feeling valued and supported at work is one of the most powerful‚Äîand meaningful‚Äîmotivators.

Fear, on the other hand, inhibits creativity and stops people from speaking up‚Ä¶but many leaders still feel it's the only way to effectively lead a team.

's new book Humane Leadership does a fantastic job helping leaders learn how to bring out the best in their teams through kindness. I encourage everyone to add it to your reading list! üìö
